tutorial.title: Stylesheet and Basic Selectors
tutorial.descriptionContent: Discover how to add colors, font styles, and formatting to make beautiful webpages with CSS.

lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent: We'll now move on to making great-looking websites with the help of a styling language called CSS, short for Cascading Style Sheets.

lessons.title: Style sheet
lessons.interactiveContent:
To make larger webpages more manageable, we can move our CSS to a style sheet, or a special file just for styling the webpage.

Make sure to pick <link rel="stylesheet" href="style.css">.

lessons.title: Linking a style sheet
lessons.interactiveContent:
To include a style sheet in an HTML file, we use the link element. <link> is a self-closing empty element and it goes inside the head element.

Make sure to pick <link>.

lessons.title: Linking a style sheet
lessons.interactiveContent:
To know what kind of file to include, the opening link tag needs the rel attribute set using rel="stylesheet".

Make sure to pick rel, followed by =, and finally "stylesheet".

lessons.title: Linking a style sheet
lessons.interactiveContent:
To specify the style sheet's location, set the href attribute to "style.css".

Make sure to pick href, followed by =, and finally "style.css".

lessons.title: Selecting
lessons.interactiveContent:
Inside the CSS file, we specify which element to style with a tag selector. Select the p⁠ tag.

Make sure to pick p.

lessons.title: Selecting
lessons.interactiveContent:
We then add an opening brace, {, followed by a closing brace, }⁠.

Make sure to pick {, followed by }.

lessons.title: Color
lessons.interactiveContent:
Now, any declaration we add will apply to all p elements on the webpage. Add the color: blue⁠;⁠ declaration.

Make sure to pick color followed by : and then blue, ;.

lessons.title: Rules
lessons.interactiveContent:
When we add p { followed by color: blue;, and then }, we create a CSS rule.

Make sure to pick p followed by { and then color: blue;, }.

lessons.title: Rules
lessons.interactiveContent: We can add other declarations like background-color: pink as long as they're on another line.

lessons.title: Question 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
How can we style a website?

By adding CSS in a style sheetBy adding JavaScript in a script

By adding CSS in a style sheet.

lessons.title: Question 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
What happens when we style elements on a webpage in an included style sheet?

Any changes to the style sheet become visible on the webpageThe elements become interactive

Any changes to the style sheet become visible on the webpage.

lessons.title: Question 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
How can we apply a style to an element?

By adding its name, braces, and the style changes in a style sheetBy using document.getElementById() in a style sheet

By adding its name, braces, and the style changes in a style sheet.

lessons.title: Question 4
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does the href attribute do in this piece of code?

It allows the link element to find the style sheetIt tells the link element what kind of file to include

It allows the link element to find the style sheet.

lessons.title: Example 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Assemble the element we use to include a style sheet.

Make sure to pick <, followed by link, and finally >.

lessons.title: Example 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Select the h1 element in the style sheet.

Make sure to pick h1.

lessons.title: Example 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Add the attribute that helps the link element find the style sheet.

Make sure to pick href.

lessons.title: Example 4
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code "stylesheet" to let the link element know what kind of file to include.

Make sure to type "stylesheet".

lessons.title: Styling the body
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we want a style to apply to the entire page, we can use the body selector.

Make sure to pick body.

lessons.title: Background color
lessons.interactiveContent:
Setting the background color to blue; inside the body rule sets the background for the entire body.

Make sure to pick blue, followed by ;.

lessons.title: Setting the text color
lessons.interactiveContent:
Styles like color: white; when set inside the body rule will apply to all elements inside the body tag.

Make sure to type color: white;.

lessons.title: Adding more style
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can style as many elements as we want as long as we add a space between different rules.

Make sure to pick h1 followed by { and then font-family: Helvetica;, }.

lessons.title: Overlapping properties
lessons.interactiveContent: Using the body tag is one of the easiest ways to add overlapping rules on elements. We'll learn about the other ways soon.

lessons.title: Question 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Why do we want to style the body element?

To apply style to all elements inside the body elementTo make the webpage interactive

To apply style to all elements inside the body element.

lessons.title: Question 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's wrong with this code?

The h1 selector is missing an opening curly braceThe h1 selector has a wrong CSS property inside

The h1 selector is missing an opening curly brace.

lessons.title: Question 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
What happens when we change the background-color of the h1 element?

The background changes only for the h1 elementsThe background changes for all elements on the webpage

The background changes only for the h1 elements.

lessons.title: Question 4
lessons.interactiveContent:
How many rules can we add to our CSS file?

As many as we wantOnly one

As many as we want.

lessons.title: Example 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Set the background color of all elements on this webpage to the value azure and the color of the heading to gray.

Make sure to pick background-color: azure;, followed by color: gray;.

lessons.title: Example 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Add the h1 selector.

Make sure to type h1.

lessons.title: Example 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Add the declaration font-style: italic; to both the rule for h3 and the rule for p tags.

Make sure to pick font-style: italic;, followed by font-style: italic;.

lessons.title: Example 4
lessons.interactiveContent:
Set background-color to the value black.

Make sure to type background-color: black;.

lessons.title: Applied to tags
lessons.interactiveContent: If there are multiple elements of the same kind on a webpage, selectors like h1, h2, or p change all of these elements.

lessons.title: Class attribute
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we want to select one or more elements, we can set a class attribute for the exact elements we want to change.

In the stylesheet, we can set a new class rule with a . followed by the name of the class. Like here with .gray-element.

Make sure to pick .gray-element.

lessons.title: Class attribute
lessons.interactiveContent:
The rules for the class will apply to all elements that have that class attribute in the html file.

Classes aren't unique, so we can set the same class for multiple elements. Like here for example, with class = "gray-element".

Make sure to pick class, followed by =, and finally "gray-element".

lessons.title: Using class
lessons.interactiveContent:
To set a class as a selector in CSS, add a period followed by the class name. In this case, it's .gray-element.

Make sure to pick ., followed by gray-element.

lessons.title: Question 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
How do we apply a style to one or more, but not all elements on a webpage?

With the class selector With the tag selector

With the class selector .

lessons.title: Question 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's wrong with this code?

The selector is missingThe property and value are missing

The selector is missing.

lessons.title: Question 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
What forms a rule?

A selector and its properties form a CSS ruleOnly properties and values form a CSS rule

A selector and its properties form a CSS rule.

lessons.title: Question 4
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's wrong with this rule?

The color property doesn't have a valueThe selector starts with a .

The color property doesn't have a value.

lessons.title: Example 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Finish assembling this class selector.

Make sure to pick . followed by completed and then {, }.

lessons.title: Example 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Add a class attribute to the li element.

Make sure to pick class, followed by =, and finally "redElement".

lessons.title: Example 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Pick the class selector to apply the rule to all elements with their class attribute set to "tealElement".

Make sure to pick .tealElement.

lessons.title: Example 4
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code .name to select the element with the class "name".

Make sure to type .name.

lessons.title: Example 5
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code the selector to select the h1 element using its class name.

Make sure to type .title.

lessons.title: Styling groups of elements
lessons.interactiveContent:
We've seen how we can use HTML tags and CSS classes to change the styles of groups of elements.

Include the button tag selector to make all buttons lightblue and the text class selector to make the texts italic.

Make sure to pick button, followed by .text.

lessons.title: Selecting one element
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we want to style a specific element, we can include an id selector. Here, we only want to select the button with the capital letter.

First, we need to identify the element in the html. To set an ID attribute, type id="".

Make sure to pick id, followed by =, and finally "".

lessons.title: Unique IDs
lessons.interactiveContent:
After the = sign, set the value of the id, "capital-letter" in this case.

ID values should be unique within the HTML document. So, we must not include a second id attribute with the same value.

Make sure to pick id, followed by =, and finally "capital-letter".

lessons.title: Using the selector
lessons.interactiveContent:
Now that we have included the id in the HTML element, we are ready to use the id selector for our styles.

To select the element by its id, we type # followed by the name of the id, like capital-letter here.

Make sure to pick #, followed by capital-letter.

lessons.title: Using the selector - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
IDs will help us with JavaScript and we shouldn't overuse them for styling. However, we can apply styles as usual with the id selector.

Include the full rule for the #capital-letter id.

Make sure to pick #capital-letter {, followed by color: blue;, and finally }.

lessons.title: Question 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
What are IDs for?

IDs identify HTML unique elementsIDs style groups of elements

IDs identify HTML unique elements.

lessons.title: Question 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
How do we set an ID attribute in the html file?

By typing id in the opening tagBy typing id between the opening and closing tags

By typing id in the opening tag.

lessons.title: Question 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
How do we use an ID selector in a stylesheet?

#id-name.id-name

Make sure to pick #id-name.

lessons.title: Question 4
lessons.interactiveContent:
Why do we say IDs are unique?

Because two elements must not have the same IDBecause they group elements

Because two elements must not have the same ID.

lessons.title: Example 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Set the id for the heading element to "title".

Make sure to pick id, followed by =, and finally "title".

lessons.title: Example 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Style the text using an ID selector.

Make sure to pick #trial.

lessons.title: Example 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Style the element with ID basketball using an ID selector in the style sheet.

Make sure to type #basketball.

lessons.title: Example 4
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's wrong with this code?

Several elements have the same idbest-friend should be in capital letters

Several elements have the same id.
